channel.title: Stories from thisiscolossal.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best thisiscolossal.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Massive Wild Animals Wander Russian Streets In These Surreal Composites By Vadim Solovyov
item.description: Seeing a raccoon washing its paws in the rivers of Saint Petersburg or an octopus tumbling out of a city bus would be a startling sight for most city dwellers.

item.title: Amazing Underwater Photographs Capture The World's Only Known Pink Manta Ray
item.description: Spanning about 11 feet and nicknamed Inspector Clouseau after "The Pink Panther," the aquatic animal lives near Lady Elliot Island, which is part of the Great Barrier Reef.

item.title: Intricate Patterns Hand-Carved Into Fruit And Vegetables By Takehiro Kishimoto
item.description: When he's not cooking them, Japanese chef and food artist Takehiro Kishimoto is turning fruits and vegetables into intricately carved sculptures too beautiful to eat.
item.kicker: ONLY HE'S ALLOWED TO PLAY WITH HIS FOOD

item.title: Aerial Photographs Of Vast Ocean Landscapes By Tobias Hägg Observe Earth's Propensity For Change
item.description: Photographing the jewel-toned waters jutting up against beaches and the salt-speckled lagoons, Tobias Hägg frames some of Earth's most striking landscapes.

item.title: Massive Ice Formations Crystalize In Incredible Photographs Of A Glacial Cave
item.description: Anchorage-based creative Paxson Woelber has captured stunning photographs that illuminate the massive ice formations he recently stumbled upon in an Alaskan cave.

item.title: A Minimalist Home In Japan Utilizes A Tent Structure With Open Air Sides
item.description: A new tent-shaped home built in a small agricultural village near Nagoka is designed with a community in mind, rather than a single family.
item.kicker: COME AND KNOCK ON OUR TENT FLAP

item.title: Swirling Fabrics Envelop Floating Subjects In These Gorgeous Underwater Photographs
item.description: By submerging her subjects into dark waters, photographer Christy Lee Rogers creates images that explore human movement in a weightless environment.

item.title: Through Monochromatic Photographs, Aleksey Myakishev Documents Rural Life In Russia
item.description: Taken mostly throughout Russia, Myakishev's projects tend to focus on unassuming subjects as they navigate their daily lives.

item.title: Aerial Embroidery Showcases The Hidden Patterns Of Cultivated Farmland
item.description: Humble fields become abstracted artworks in thread paintings by Victoria Rose Richards.

item.title: These Intricate Battleships Are Constructed From Vintage Newspaper
item.description: The Japanese visual artist Atsushi Adachi creates miniature replicas of objects from the past using old newspaper clippings and articles sourced from the same period.

item.title: These Gorgeous 'Impossible Cityscapes' Draw Inspiration From Cartography And Musical Compositions
item.description: These illustrations by Benjamin Sack are unreal to behold.

item.title: London's Imperfect Geometry Revealed In Aerial Photography
item.description: Munich-based photographer Bernhard Lang recently shared aerial views of famous squares and landmarks throughout London, England. By presenting the metropolis from the sky, Lang offers a more dynamic look at the capital city's unique geometric patterns and iconic architecture.

item.title: The Elaborate Underground Architecture Of Soviet Metro Stations, In Photos
item.description: Photographer Christopher Herwig's new book provides rare look at mansion-quality chandeliers, ornate columns, and patterned ceilings that surround millions of commuters every day.

item.title: Manmade Patterns and Uncanny Shadows Photographed From Above
item.description: Using a drone, JP and Mike Andrews have continued to capture natural and manmade scenes across the world, stumbling upon unique patterns that can only be discerned from above.

item.title: Surreal Blue Spheres of Ice Juxtaposed with Everyday Life Document the Unrelenting Pace of Melting Glaciers
item.description: Using data compiled from scientific reports, photographer Dillon Marsh calculated and scaled the volumetric ice models for specific mountains that are losing their critically important glaciers.

item.title: A Sharp Look at the Surprisingly Complex Process of Pencil Manufacturing
item.description: Photographer Christopher Payne spent several years building a relationship with the owners of one of the last remaining pencil factories in the United States. Between fall 2015 and summer 2017 Payne was granted access to the production floor for photo-documentation more than thirty times.
item.kicker: PUTTING A FINE POINT ON THEM

item.title: A Rare Tropical Glacier Captured At Night In Drone-Illuminated Photographs
item.description: Peru's Pastoruri Glacier is a rare remaining tropical glacier, sited at 17,000 feet above sea level in the Cordillera Blanca mountain range.

item.title: Macro Infrared Photographs Unlock the Depth of Green in a Stunning Array of Canary Island Plants
item.description: Marcus Wendt, creative director at the London-based studio Field, recently traveled to the island of Lanzarote to shoot a series of macro images of the region's native plants. His project,

item.title: Commodity City: A Fascinating Glimpse Inside the World's Largest Wholesale Market
item.description: ﻿ ﻿ The Yiwu International Trade Market in China is the world's largest wholesale market, stretching nearly five miles and containing over 75,000 individual vendors. Chinese-American film director Jessica Kingdon peeks into the daily lives of the market's workers in her observational documentary Commodity City, exploring the subtle interactions that occur amongst hoards of dolls, flowers, neon signs, […]

item.title: A Rare Glimpse at a Deserted Great Wall of China Captured by Andres Gallardo Albajar
item.description: This past February architectural photographer Andres Gallardo Albajar traveled to the Great Wall of China where he was able to take in a rare sight — one of the seven wonders of the world without a single soul to be seen.

item.title: The Wines of Gala: Salvador Dalí's Surrealist Wine Guide Republished for the First Time in 40 Years
item.description: In keeping with Dalí's efforts to create artwork based on his emotions, memories, and dreams, the artist chose to organize the wines in the book by how they influenced his mood.
item.kicker: YOU SHOULD BE DRUNK BEFORE YOU READ IT

item.title: The Absurdly Elongated Sculptural Objects of the Dufala Brothersby Kate Sierzputowski on October 13, 2016
item.description: The Dufala Brothers have a knack for the surreal, creating modern objects that have been elongated and stretched into abstract versions of shoes, household appliances, and tools.

item.title: Unseen Art: 3D Printing Classical Paintings for the Blind
item.description: "You can look but you can't touch." That's one of the first rules of museums, which house priceless works of art. But what about the community of blind and visually impaired who use their sense of touch to experience the world?
item.kicker: PLEASE DON'T LOOK AT THE ARTWORK

item.title: Journalist Spends Four Years Traversing India to Document Crumbling Subterranean Stepwells Before they Disappear
item.description: Stepwells, like gates to the underworld, are massive subterranean temples designed as a primary way to access the water table in regions where the climate vacillates between swelteringly dry during most months and torrential monsoons in the spring. Now they're forgotten, ignored and crumbling quickly.

item.title: The Motions of Kayaking and Canoeing Recorded through Light Painting on Canadian Waterways
item.description: Kayaking Canoeing Kayaking Kayaking Kayaking Canoeing Kayaking Kayaking Swimming Ontario-based photographer Stephen Orlando is fascinated with human movement and uses programmable LED light sticks attached to kayak paddles, people, racquets, and other objects to translate that movement into photographic light paintings. The act of recording motion on the surface of water surrounded by reflections creates […]

item.title: Turn Boring Vegetables into Spaceships and Racecars with Le FabShop's 3D-Printable 'Open Toys'
Only Nails, Always Different: Artist John Bisbee's Life of Sculpting with Nails
item.description: John Bisbee has spent nearly 30 years using nails as his sole medium to create geometric sculptures, organic installations, and unwieldy objects from thousands of nails that are hammered, bent, welded, or fastened together in a seemingly limitless procession of forms.

item.title: The Ingenuity and Beauty of Creative Parchment Repair in Medieval Books
item.description: Parchment was extremely delicate and costly to manufacture well, so imperfections from animal hair follicles to small tears and texture anomalies were left for the poor scribes to contend with.
item.kicker: YOU CAN'T JUST PUT A BAND AID ON IT

item.title: Dizzying New GIFs at the Intersection of Art and Math by Dave Whyte
item.description: Starting this month Verizon FiOS customers can get upload speeds every bit as fast as their download speeds. Since that means faster, easier sharing of high-res illustrations, designs, and photos, FiOS is sponsoring a series of posts on Colossal to help us commission and share these super hi-res animated GIFs from some of the most […]

item.title: Breathtaking Aerial Landscapes of Iceland by Sarah Martinet
item.description: While on a recent trip to Iceland, photographer Sarah Martinet had the opportunity to shoot these amazing landscapes from a plane with open windows.

item.title: X-Rayed Toys by Brendan Fitzpatrick
item.description: Photographer Brendan Fitzpatrick just released three new collections of x-ray photos including toys, creatures, and a new set of flowers, as part of his "Invisible Light" series.

item.title: Custom Engraved Rolling Pins Imprint Patterns into Cookie Dough
item.description: Polish designer Zuzia Kozerska creates laser-engraved wooden rolling pins that print designs onto cookie dough. They look almost too good to eat.
item.kicker: THE WAY THE AWESOME COOKIE CRUMBLES

item.title: This is a GIF of a Vine of a Video of a Flipbook of a GIF of a Video of a Roller Coaster
item.description: Our minds have been blown.

item.title: The Cyanometer Is a 225-Year-Old Tool for Measuring the Blueness of the Sky
271 Years Before Pantone, an Artist Mixed and Described Every Color Imaginable in an 800-Page Book
item.description: In 1692 an artist known only as "A. Boogert" sat down to write a book in Dutch about mixing watercolors. Not only would he begin the book with a bit about the use of color in painting, but would go on to explain how to create certain hues and change the tone by adding one, two, or three parts of water. The premise sounds simple enough, but the final product is almost unfathomable in its detail and scope.

item.title: Intricately Carved Goose Shells by Piotr Bockenheim
item.description: Unless you spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours with a tiny electric drill carving intricate patterns into eggshells the last few months, you may have yet to reach your Easter egg decorating potential.

item.title: The Bizarre World of Chicken Beauty Pageants Photographed by Ernest Goh
item.description: Photographer and visual artist Ernest Goh is known for his work photographing wildlife and other animals. His latest book documents the strange world of chicken beauty pageants in Malaysia where he encountered a breed of bird called the Ayam Seramas, an ornate chicken raised not for its meat but purely for its appearance.

item.title: The Beauty of Japan's Artistic Manhole Covers
item.description: For the past several years photographer S. Morita has traveled around Japan photographing artistic manhole covers.

item.title: High Speed Photos of Combusting Alcohol Look like X-Rays of the Human Brain
item.description: The plume from an exploding bomb. Black and white flowers. X-Rays of a human brain cortex. These all seem like valid guesses when looking at this new series of photos but the truth is more amazing: it's fire.

item.title: The Mini Museum: A Desktop Museum with Dinosaur Fragments, Apollo 11 Spacecraft, the Moon, and More
item.description: For the past 35 years designer Hans Fex has been collecting some of the Earth's most rare historical specimens including a fossil of a palm tree from Antarctica, wrap from a mummy, coal from the Titanic, dinosaur bones, and even a piece of the Apollo 11 command module.

item.title: Desert Breath: A Monumental Land Art Installation in the Sahara Desert
item.description: Located near the Red Sea in El Gouna, Egypt, Desert Breath is an impossibly immense land art installation dug into the sands of the Sahara desert by the D.A.ST. Arteam back in 1997.

item.title: A 19th Century Lithographer Transforms the Alphabet into a Series of Sweeping Landscapes
item.description: Buried in the archives of the British Museum is this wonderful series of lithographs from illustrator Charles Joseph Hullmandel that transforms the English alphabet into sweeping landscapes.

item.title: Ingenious Door Opens and Closes Like Folded Paper
Carcass: A Scale Replica of a Fast Food Kitchen Carved Entirely from Wood by Roxy Paine
item.description: It's clear this is an expertly executed replica of a fast food restaurant counter complete with order screens, straw dispensers and a soft-serve ice cream machine; but devoid of flashy logos, food, or any other visual cues whatsoever, all that seems to remain is an empty shell—a carcass—carved entirely from birch and maple wood.

item.title: The Incredible Underwater Art of Competitve Aquascaping
item.description: No, these aren't exactly your childhood goldfish bowls. The world of competitive aquarium design, or aquascaping, is just as difficult, expensive, and cutthroat as any other sport but requires expertise in many different fields to guarantee success.

item.title: Humorous Street Art and Urban Interventions by SpY
item.description: Like Banksy, but with a sense of humor.

item.title: The Last Thing You Would See If You Were Eaten by a Penguin
item.description: G Adventures While exploring Antarctica aboard the M/S Expedition, the folks over at G Adventures snapped this wild perspective of a Gentoo penguin attacking their GoPro camera. The photo was shared on their Twitter account where they regularly document the sights of ongoing adventure cruises. Related: an eagle steals a GoPro camera.

item.title: Rare Temperature Inversion Creates River of Clouds Inside the Grand Canyon
item.description: Last week the Grand Canyon experienced a rare temperature inversion where cool air began to rise from the bottom of the canyon and met warm air above creating incredible low level clouds.

item.title: The Hubble Telescope Photographs Messier 15, One of the Densest Clusters of Stars Ever Discovered
item.description: This recently released photograph from the Hubble Telescope captures the spectacular glory of Messier 15 located about 35,000 light-years away. It might be hard to believe, but if you were to look up in the sky and locate the constellation Pegasus, this entire cluster of stars is located inside of it. It is one of […]

item.title: A 15th Century Cathedral Transformed into a Modern Bookstore
